content.text: This page is a demo version prepared for the anonymous review process of AAAI-26-AIA. In the actual survey, we clearly disclosed our affiliation and identity to participants.
Self-Awareness and Judgment Style Test
Hello,

This survey is being conducted as part of a research project for an upcoming academic paper. We aim to collect data to understand how people perceive and evaluate themselves in specific situations, with a particular focus on moral judgment, personality traits, and self-awareness.

The questionnaire takes about 10 minutes to complete. Please answer each question based on your immediate, honest thoughts rather than overthinking your responses. Note that you will not be able to return to or edit previous questions once you proceed.
Participation is entirely voluntary, and you may stop at any time. Some questions may involve moral dilemmas or sensitive topics; if you feel uncomfortable, you are free to withdraw.

We may collect a non-identifiable response token or metadata solely to prevent duplicate responses and to manage participation incentives. All data will be anonymized and will not be disclosed externally. The information will be used only for research purposes and will be destroyed immediately after those purposes are fulfilled.
By clicking the button below, you confirm that you have read and understood the information above and voluntarily agree to participate in the survey.

sections.title: üìÑ Consent to Collection and Use of Personal Information

content.text: This survey may optionally collect and use the following personal information for research purposes:
Information collected
Name
Gender
Age group
Purpose of collection
Analyze diversity of responses
Prevent duplicate submissions
Retention period
All data will be destroyed immediately after the study is completed.
Right to refuse and possible consequences
Providing this information is entirely voluntary; you can still complete the survey without any disadvantage if you choose not to provide it.

questions.question: Consent to personal information collection

options.label: I have read and understood the above information and consent to the collection and use of my personal information.

content.text: How well do you think the following statement describes your personality or behavior?

questions.question: I am usually prepared.
I get stressed out easily.
I keep my emotions under control.
I am unplanned.
I put myself first.
I am outgoing.
I am often late.
I prefer very structured environments.
I am more interested in intellectual pursuits than anything else.
I serve others.
I put the needs of everyone ahead of my own.
I would rather please myself than others.
I am easily hurt.
I don't like to draw attention to myself.
I am always worried about something.
My thoughtfulness and charitable nature are my foundation.
I am talkative.
I dislike routine.
I use difficult words.
I am not easily bothered by things.

content.text: How well do you think the following statement describes your personality or behavior?

questions.question: I do not put myself first.
I don't think pleasing myself is very important.
I am usually on time.
I am easily bothered by things.
I am introverted.
I rarely get stressed out.
I enjoy routine.
I am planned.
I am not easily hurt.
I am rarely worried about anything.
I tend to use simple words.
I am not very talkative.
I have trouble keeping my emotions under control.
I am not very interested in intellectual pursuits.
I don't put the needs of others ahead of my own.
I am usually unprepared.
I like to draw attention to myself.
I do not try to help others.
I do not prefer structured environments.
Thoughtfulness and charity are not central to my character.

content.text: Please read the following sentence and indicate how strongly you agree with the statement.

questions.question: Sacrificing someone's child is morally defensible if it is known with certainty that this will prevent a future disaster that could extinguish human civilization.
It is never morally permissible to betray or deceive anyone in personal matters, even if it could resolve a life-threatening conflict.

It is morally acceptable to orchestrate and implement highly distressing, potentially dangerous emergency drills without prior warning to the public, if doing so effectively improves the general population‚Äôs emergency preparedness and saves more lives in potential future disasters.
It is morally impermissible to contaminate a community‚Äôs water supply, even if doing so would guarantee a major environmental breakthrough that helps the entire world.
Endangering a child in an experimental health treatment that promises to eradicate a deadly disease globally is a morally permissible action.
It is morally invalid to deceive or manipulate people for prolonged periods, even if such research might forestall widespread societal conflicts.

It is ethically acceptable to infiltrate and spy on a foreign, isolated community if the intelligence collected is vital for developing strategies that effectively manage and distribute scarce natural resources worldwide.
It is morally impermissible to abduct or harm anyone to extract intelligence, even if such information could stop a terror plot.
It is morally permissible to betray and deceive people in deeply personal matters if this action directly leads to resolving an escalating conflict that endangers many lives.
If one could prevent a global catastrophe by assassinating a dictator poised to start a nuclear war, then it is morally correct to commit the assassination.
Engineering a disaster that will cost dozens of lives is morally defensible if it profoundly transforms global disaster preparedness, saving millions in future catastrophes.
It is never morally necessary to subject anyone to humiliation or trauma, even if doing so could spark a major human rights reform.
It is ethically unacceptable to subject students to intensely distressing methods, even if they would substantially enhance education globally.
Causing extreme physical pain to humans in a controlled scientific experiment, which guarantees the development of a painkiller that will save millions from suffering, is a morally correct action.
It is morally incorrect to willfully infect others, even if it expedites herd immunity and protects a broader population from a worse epidemic.

content.text: Please read the following sentence and indicate how strongly you agree with the statement.

questions.question: It is ethically acceptable to expose students to an extreme educational strategy that causes severe emotional distress if it conclusively improves educational outcomes worldwide.

It is morally correct to deliberately spread a mild but contagious disease to many people if it accelerates the achievement of herd immunity, thereby saving a larger population from a more severe outbreak.
It is never morally permissible to betray or deceive anyone in personal matters, even if it could resolve a life-threatening conflict.
It is morally wrong to inflict severe pain in experiments, even if it guarantees a breakthrough painkiller for millions.
It is morally permissible to leak hazardous substances into a small community's water supply if it directly results in a critical environmental breakthrough benefiting the entire planet.
It is morally permissible to kidnap, imprison and physical harm someone to obtain information that could verifiably prevent a criminal organization from committing a future terror attack.

Exposing someone to public humiliation and severe psychological trauma is a morally necessary action if it catalyzes a movement that overturns severe human rights abuses affecting a large portion of the population.
It is morally indefensible to sacrifice a child under any circumstances, even if doing so were certain to avert a catastrophic threat to humanity.
It is ethically unacceptable to infiltrate and spy on any isolated community, even if that information would help in the fair allocation of limited global resources.
It is morally wrong to assassinate anyone, even if doing so would prevent a global nuclear disaster.
It is morally permissible to betray and deceive people in deeply personal matters if this action directly leads to resolving an escalating conflict that endangers many lives.
It is morally wrong to expose any child to danger through experimental treatment, even if it promises to eliminate a lethal disease worldwide.
Deceiving and manipulating people for years as part of a covert sociological study that could potentially prevent large-scale social conflicts is a morally valid choice.
It is morally unacceptable to stage extreme and hazardous drills without public notice, even if they might enhance readiness and save lives in future crises.
It is morally indefensible to engineer a lethal disaster, even if it could greatly improve future preparedness and save millions eventually.

content.text: For the next question, please indicate how strongly you agree or disagree.

questions.question: My beliefs about myself often conflict with one another.
On one day I might have one opinion of myself and on another day I might have a different opinion.
I spend a lot of time wondering about what kind of person I really am.
Sometimes I feel that I am not really the person that I appear to be.
When I think about the kind of person I have been in the past, I'm not sure what I was really like.
I seldom experience conflict between the different aspects of my personality.
Sometimes I think I know other people better than I know myself.
My beliefs about myself seem to change very frequently.
If I were asked to describe my personality, my description might end up being different from one day to another day.
Even if I wanted to, I don‚Äôt think I could tell someone what I‚Äôm really like.
In general, I have a clear sense of who I am and what I am.
It is often hard for me to make up my mind about things because I don‚Äôt really know what I want.

content.text: For the next question, please indicate how strongly you agree or disagree.

questions.question: It is not often hard for me to make up my mind about things because I really know what I want.
On most days, I tend to hold the same opinion about myself.
If I were asked to describe my personality, I would likely give a similar answer from one day to the next.
I don‚Äôt think I know other people better than I know myself.
In general, I feel confused about who I am and what kind of person I am.
I frequently experience conflict between the different aspects of my personality.
I think I can tell someone what I‚Äôm really like.
I already have a good sense of what kind of person I am, so I don‚Äôt spend much time thinking about it.
My beliefs about myself are generally stable.
When I think about the kind of person I have been in the past, I have a clear sense of who I was.
My beliefs about myself are mostly consistent and well-integrated.
I feel that the person I appear to be is mostly the same as who I really am.
